$P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$?
inference:
If \(P(x)\) is divided by \(x-13\), the remainder is \(19\), so \(P(13)=19\).

If \(P(x)\) is divided by \(x+17\), the remainder is \(-11\), so \(P(-17)=-11\).

By the Remainder Theorem, 
$$P(x)=(x-13)Q_1(x)+19,$$

and 

$$P(x)=(x+17)Q_2(x)-11.$$

Substituting \(x=13\) in the first equation gives

$$P(13)=19=(13-13)Q_1(13)+19=19.$$

Substituting \(x=-17\) in the second equation gives

$$P(-17)=-11=(-17+17)Q_2(-17)-11=-11.$$

Therefore, by the Factor Theorem, \(x-13\) and \(x+17\) are factors of \(P(x)\).

Hence, when \(P(x)\) is divided by \((x-13)(x+17)\), the remainder is \(0\) since it is divisible by both \(x-13\) and \(x+17\).

Final Answer: \boxed{$0$}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Since we are dividing by a quadratic, the remainder will have degree less than 2. So the remainder $r(x)=ax+b$ for some constants $a$ and $b$. We have,
$$P(x) = (x-13)(x+17)Q(x) +ax+b$$where $Q(x)$ is the quotient of the division.

Then, using the Remainder Theorem,
$$\begin{aligned} P(13) &= 13a+b = 19 \\
P(-17) &= -17a+b = -11 \end{aligned}$$.
Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$. So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.
